title: Before 1 January 2021, will Apple officially announce a ridesharing partnership with a major automaker?
preds: The question time frame is why I only give it a 2% probability.

"AppsFlyer Launches First Global Attribution Solution for Apple’s App Clips" " 'Consumer-facing digital innovations like App Clips are transforming how mobile customers interact with the most valuable components of an app service or capability,' said Brian Quinn, US President and General Manager, AppsFlyer. 'Brands have already started integrating App Clips into their mobile strategy and we’re seeing gains in adoption from people who prefer using a frictionless and lightning-fast App Clip to do things like buy a cup of coffee or hail a rideshare instead of installing a full app. We recognized early on that an attribution solution for App Clips was going to be a necessary tool for app marketers to understand the full impact of their mobile strategy.' "
https://martechseries.com/mobile/mobile-marketing/appsflyer-launches-first-global-attribution-solution-apples-app-clips/

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-28/uber-said-to-weigh-purchase-of-bmw-daimler-ride-hailing-venture This might increase pressure on Apple with a big IF: if they're interested in that market at all and intend to enter, the time is obviously now, before all claims have been pegged out (amazon is said to be interested in ride-hailing, too: Zoox). Interestingly, the DriveNow a.k.a. FreeNow business of Daimler and BMW appears to be up for sale right now, so it will be interesting to watch whether there will be counter offers to UBER's bid, and whether Apple will be among those potential bidders. If Apple takes over an affiliate company of one or more major auto makers, to me the logical consequence would be there will be some long-term co-operations concerning car purchases, maintenance in authorized workshops, original spare part supply and /or leasing agreements with these very auto makers. In my view this would fulfill the question's condition of "ridesharing partnership with a major automaker" with Apple, and thus would resolve the question.
Apple has already made a series of recent hardware and software announcements.

Apple today announced a few novelties, many changes to their streaming-, gaming-, music-business, and new flat fee models for an Apple health service, besides a new AirPad, Apple Watches, and new chips and architectures, as far as I leafed through.
A ridesharing partnership was not among the new services, AFAIK. However, this would be such a big innovation and new business model, it would certainly be worth a separate and surprising announcement invitation to the press for Apple. However, the time is running out, I'll join the crowd in skepticism for the time being.

Apple siempre ha estado en la vanguardia de tecnologías disruptivas, y en mi opinión los autos eléctricos van a ser uno de los grandes cambios que se van a generar en esta década, donde tener uno va a ser tan normal como tener un Iphone. Si bien pienso que los autos no van a tener el logo Apple, pero que sí la compañía va a estar involucrada en las investigaciones y desarrollo de estos.
I've done very poorly on questions about EVs and AVs a couple years ago.  I was way over-optimistic.

Reasons
1. Since it's not about if, but when.
2. Apple will wait till COVID is behind us and social distancing is in the past.
3. So Apple will wait till end of 2021.
Apple will be partnering with the company that is offering solid state batteries and cars with no steering wheels.
There are no synergies and in the current climate such a partnership makes no sense to Apple

With the possibility of an economic downturn and/or collapse, a pandemic keeping many people indoors and away from one another, and a federal government more keen to cut regulations than subsidize advancements, a rideshare partnership between two big names new to the field makes little sense (or perhaps none at all). Now is the time to hunker down and stick with your demonstrably profitable business ventures, not try to branch out and attack a new market.

Dropping to zero. Apple has other ways of making money, many other ways. They could certainly handle payments and handle a key sharing arrangement, but what are the synergies with their other businesses and do they really want to be associated with a side effort?

Partnerships surrounding rideshare companies make little sense for a company as profitable as Apple at the moment. Fewer people are traveling, and even less are using services that involve traveling with strangers. More likely, Apple will continue to hunker down, stick to its successful product line, and ride out the pandemic in a more fiscally responsible way.
With overall discretionary travel continuing the demand for ride-sharing will c continue to be suppressed into 2021
This is too big a shift for Apple’s focus. Makes no sense. They won’t go this direction.

Extremely unlikely given the Apple product roadmap. First, they will release the AR headset. They also just announced the ability to open cars with their keys so they are making progress towards this - albeit slowly.
CarKey is not a service as currently defined.
I'll meet @SE_Meyer half-way on this one. The definition of a service or a feature is important in this question. With clairfication, 100% is clearly possible.

If...
...Mercedes and Smart, which will deliver eSmart vehicles only soon, will announce to support Apple CarKey (despite of their own proprietary MBUX OS) soon
...ShareNow (a Joint Venture of Daimler's "CAR2GO" and BMW's "DriveNow") will announce to add BMW's new 5series to their fleet
this will strongly indicate that what can be interpreted as a partnership enabling ridesharing at the moment will turn into a full-scale ridesharing partnership with an affiliate of two major German car manufacturers.
The question I would like to have clarified before is: will the total ownership of an affiliate company, irrespective of the dispersion of ownership, be treated and regarded as if the car manufacturer itself entered the partnership and thus be a sufficient condition to the answer "YES"? Technicalities, technicalities... I wish they would pay more attention to these details when they design the questionnaire from the start to spare us demanding clarification.

"Apple is debuting CarKey, its digital car keys coming in iOS 13 and iOS 14
"Apple introduced a new way to unlock and start your car, well, just the BMW 5-series for now. You can register a key in your Apple Wallet, and when you walk up to a supported car, you’ll unlock it via NFC, then start the engine once your phone is resting on a pad. The keys are stored on-device, and it can be deleted from the cloud if you need to. What’s also cool about this feature is that you can create unique driving profiles for other iPhone users, giving user-specific permissions for, say, your kid, or no restrictions at all for someone else, like a spouse or other trusted person. "   (I have asked for clarification is this feature a SERVICE?)

From msn.com regarding Apple WWDC held last week: "Apple also wants you to use your iPhone or Apple Watch as a car key, using the near-field communication standard. The BMW 5 Series will be the first car to support the system. This will arrive even sooner in iOS 13 as well." Does this fulfill the "RIDESHARING PARTNERSHIP" of this question? Certainly with an app on your iPhone you could provide a "key" to another person's iPhone that would open and operate your vehicle. Nothing in the announcement descibed a service, only a feature controlling the car with your phone. This question is too nebulous to reach a conclusion. Oh, yes who provides the disinfectant wipe down of the vehicle between uses? Is there an App for that?
Cutting forecast in half. There are so many more fish to fry....this one seems too little too late. Last year's great idea perhaps.

I am going to guess that future capabilites of CarPlay will include many things some of which could allow temporary keys. But for the timeframe of this question I don't see anything happening. People are still selling 2019 model year cars as new.

Hattip to @SE_Meyer for suggesting that a phone based key would allow temporary key assignments to others for your CarPlay enabled auto. A phone based key has advantages for the user and could temporarily assign "key rights" to others with similarly equipped phones, thus enabling car sharing. This is a stretch of course, but only a matter of software and Apple can provide both sides of it. It would be nice to eliminate the key bulge in my pocket.

https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/22/tech/apple-car-key/index.html "While Apple's years-long ambition to build its own vehicle hasn't materialized, its CarPlay infotainment system is available in 97% of new cars, according to the company. And it thinks that the humble car key, which on new cars can take the shape of your vehicle, or even feature a screen of its own, can still be improved further.
[...]
Apple is working with standards groups to pave the way for expanding the technology to more cars. Federighi said it expects to see support for the new ultra wideband standard in new vehicles next year.
In May, an industry group, the Car Connectivity Consortium, announced a standardized way to store digital keys. Its members include major automakers and tech companies such as Apple, BMW, GM, Honda, Hyundai, Samsung and Volkswagen."
They will focus on Apple Car Play for all cars.
With the current climate, the appetite for ride sharing is very low. Apple would not want to enter into such an enterprise.

Apple has already dipped it's toe into the ridesharing game and partnered with the biggest rideshare company in the world, but their interests seem to be in data. So, right now, I don't see why they would partner with a major automaker -- maybe in a few years when Mercedes really gets the ball rolling with AVs.

Reasons
Apple for all of its innovation branding, is a very conservative company when it comes to timing its products. 
At a time when ride share is close to zero is not a time Apple will announce a partnership that would be dead on arrival.
Instead expect a budget I-phone to hit the market.
Given current economic conditions and forecasts, need for social distancing etc. until COVID vaccine is found, the payback of a new venture the makes social distancing difficult is unlikely

Ride-sharing usage is down and will continue to be so while coronavirus is an issue, which it will be. On the other hand, a truly autonomous (no one else in the car) transport service would be a huge boon during coronavirus. However, given the struggles other companies have had in developing truly autonomous vehicles, the length of time for the regulatory environment to become developed and certain enough, and the unsteady economy, no way do I think that Apple mobilizes in that potential market by January 2021.
If they figure out technology to trace COVID, there could be some synergy here
Ride sharing usage is being pummeled by coronavirus. Apple will hold off and see if the industry recovers.
Apple need for R&D with the $1B it invested in Chinese ride share company Didi Chuxing. I believe they will have something started by the middle to end of 2021.
I feel....they are not into spreading their wings more than they do, inside this "worst of all years"!
If there was no Coronavirus that would be a possibility but ride sharing is not doing well

Apple have bigger fish to fry and they need to work out the inhouse sales of their own products which would of had an unpredictable financial year due to COVID and the current state of the world around job loss and economy. I think you'll see apple currency and apple bank potentially soon

Between the corporate agreements and Corona ... the timing is unlikely. I also don't believe it is a priority, but there is a risk of a throw away partnership - nothing designed to accomplish any more than some PR.
Possible,but likely too early. Not sure why it would be with a specific automaker

Apple rarely surprise the market with the categories - they surprise in the execution. If they were to launch such a program there would already be whispers, if not from Apple, then from someone within the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers industry.

Cutting my forecast in half again as I just don't see the chemistry or the advantages to Apple's business model. Perhaps when we have an outpost and a working water mine on the moon this will make sense, but not this year.

Only going this high because Apple showed interest in Lyft and self-driving cars in previous years.  Current economy and COVID-19 side effects (higher unemployment, car sales slumps, etc.) makes market unattractive, and outside Apple's core business.

Cant presently see apple going into a partnership with anyone.
Buying a company , yes , but that's a different question.

Cutting my forecast in half as others have observed there does not appear to be motivation to enter ridesharing as it's not a viable business at the moment.
If Apple had a Full Self Driving suite, anything is possible, but alas no one has a level 5 capability today or likely next year. Some may be approaching level 4, but not Apple to my knowledge.

COVID19 may accelerate the move to autonomy, the muted moves of the likes amazon to buy into further technology may stimulate Apple into action and secure meaningful ground in the data and intelligence stakes.  Any partnership is likely to come outside of the United States.  The French stimulus may be one area. https://www.reddit.com/r/SelfDrivingCarsLie/comments/gih1k5/apple_and_uber_have_fallen_behind_in_the_race_to/

Rideshare partnership? What was I thinking? Why on earth would they or anyone get into rideshare?
Especially now, especially with the current revenue model.
I don't know, there is nothing innovative about the current model and having driver contractors, not to mention contrary to Apple's quality and branding control standards. If and when autonomous vehicles become a thing and there is an EV rush, then maybe... but for now, without some dramatic change to the model, this seems unlikely. Think different.

From a financial viewpoint ridesharing is not a very attractive business (unless you treat your drivers as 'contractors' or eliminate completely them by self driven cars). Not an Apple kind of business.  But from a societal viewpoint, Ridesharing has its positives (especially when you combine it with semi auto driving and electric). That is an Apple kind of business (at least when you look outside from Apple perspective).  Apple also has much bigger and more immediate fish to fry - AR/VR (or whatever is the next evolution of computing interfaces), TV/Entertainment (getting more Share of Device in households), cloud, the whole China situation etc.  So we might see Apple getting into electric batteries, self driving etc. But tying up with a Ford or Renault in order to run a ridesharing business with their unsold cars? Very slim chances in 2020.  So starting off with a baseline of 3% for Yes. To be revised to 0% as the year proceeds.
Seems less likely with coronavirus. But who knows?

Updating my original forecast. I think my rough estimate of 1 in 200 for each automaker was a little high, considering the current situation. Let's say there's a 1 in 600 chance that Apple partners with any particular automaker. Then the probability that there is a partnership with any of the 50 automakers is 1 - (0.998)^50 = 8%.
With cv19 and economic downturn, it's unlikely ridesharing will be embraced by individuals. What is more likely is driving individual cars will increase as people avoid public transit.
Cutting my forecast in half as I still cannot visualize what Apple would bring to the party and why it would partner with one autormaker.

Cutting by a third as I cannot imagine how it would play out. There are multiple ridesharing companies and the market is saturated and with a reduced clientel. And no one has Full Self Driving at the level required for AV, certainly not Apple.
Makes sense as this will be compatible with all their electronic applications and hardware.
Apple has decreased current testing of self-driving cars.

Doesn't appear likely at least for this year. Covid-19 may be a negative factor, esp. with testing.  Some article links: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/12/technology/self-driving-cars-coronavirus.html https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-uber-may-end-self-driving-projects-covid-19-2020-5 https://appleinsider.com/articles/20/02/27/apple-greatly-reduced-self-driving-car-testing-in-2019-fleet-of-23-vehicles-drove-only-7500-miles

Leaning on the lower end, for a few reasons: -If Apple were to go into the rideshare business, I would imagine they would more go the route of purchasing a Lyft-type company that was already doing so (although they've shied away from that in the past), rather than partnering with an automaker. -In general, the rideshare business seems to have a number of labor issues/also the issue of people being less interested in sharing a car with a strange due to Covid. Still giving it some chance though, as Apple may view this as an opportunity with Uber/Lyft potentially struggling due to the issues above.
Autonomous driving is coming faster than we think, and Apple being one of our leading tech companies will be out in front of this too.
Seems unlikely ... what would be the concrete business strategy behind it?
Not one of the Apple strategic priorities
Not much clear info, though Apple has invested heavily in companies such as Uber.

I feel I am being charitable with my forecast. The automotive industry is in chaotic stress as they invest in EV's and AV's and try to keep us buying ICE's. Apple on the other hand has a very profitbale franchise in personal electronics and a market leadership position. I can see Apple adding value in autos via their existing franchise, but to pick a winner and limit their money and influence to that winner would seem unlikely, limiting and doomed. Disclosure: I have been wrong before.

There is almost no information tying Apple to any automaker at this point. With that in mind, the given time frame seems quite short. I don't think this is super likely. For the sake of providing a rough estimate, let's assume that there's a 1 in 200 chance that Apple partners with any particular automaker in the next 7 months. Then the probability that there is a partnership with any of the 50 automakers is 1 - (0.995)^50 = 22%.

My guess is, that Apple, via its Asset Management Segment Braeburn Capital simply takes over (or at least become a major shareholder in) a large European car manufacturing company, such as Renault, which are supposed to be in financial trouble right now. By helping out the French government, which would probably have to nationalize Renault otherwise, Apple could achieve pacification in their relationship to France, which are now contaminated by the French digital tax, in exchange for a guarantee for Renault's long term existence.
With its Renault Z.E. product line, it's one of the more innovative car manufacturers, however probably lacking a consistent strategy, an OS and a proprietary car entertainment system, a global reach and financial fire power for further development (as most manufacturers at the moment).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault_Fluence_Z.E.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault%E2%80%93Nissan%E2%80%93Mitsubishi_Alliance#Zero-emission_vehicles
In that way, Apple could contribute to the EVs' further market penetration without bearing the risk of constructing and operating factories themselves. I do see some industrial logic, and at the current market valuations, traditional car makers and their assets (brand value etc.) are for grabs at or below book value, while tech companies are awash with cash without a breakthrough innovative idea or product generation in the past few years.
Starting here as a knee-jerk baseline...
